[Swahili for "My Mom, I love you very much!]” - Sean Muriithi, Animator on Soul #BlackHistoryMonth #InsidePixar I knew early on that I did not aspire to be in the medical field because I did not possess the passion to do so like many others in my family; however, I knew I could still help the world as my Mom does through a different medium. I know a lot of people in my community can relate when I say our parents are never too excited to hear us say, ‘I want to do arts,’ because it's always about science, business, or law. But again, the industry needs our voices and it needs us to tell our stories. It's unfortunate to say, but there aren't a lot of African-Americans in the animation industry and I hope this film touches my community and illustrates to them that your dreams are achievable, you can make it, you just have to be willing to take those risks. As artists, we face many challenges during the day whether they be big or small. One of those battles we face is representation. I hope when people watch SOUL, they are inspired to chase their dream regardless of what obstacles or hardships they might face. She's a true inspiration because she is rarely faced with an issue that she cannot eradicate. I've seen her go through the toughest of battles, but she always rises to the top. I try to keep that in my mind as motivation as I'm working in this industry. Whether I had trouble at school with a teacher, got stuck on the road with car troubles, or if I just needed someone to annoy, she was always there. She's not just a hero to me and my siblings, but to several others as well - She's a nurse and she saves lives every day. “If I were to pick one person that inspires me the most, it would be my Mom. Since my father passed away when I was little, she's always been the champion in my eyes that comes in to save the day. https://t.co/ZqBYWJeMPF It’s necessary for all of us to uphold the many who fought for better days, and to never lose sight that they are the expression and definition of human love & compassion.” #BlackHistoryMonth #InsidePixar I thought I knew the meaning of Black History, but I was so wrong. Black History is necessary for all of us to know, see and learn from the many that took the high-road. It takes real courage and love to face evil for over 400 years and walk right through it.
A few months ago, I took a trip to the National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington D.C, and I walked away with a punch to the gut. It’s important for me to always keep in mind and heart those who’ve come before me, and the sacrifices they have made. I wouldn’t be here if it weren’t for those who believed in a brighter, better future. MonatQue Ruffin - Animator on Soul

If your aspiration is to work for Pixar, it is invaluable to gain professional experience as a software engineer through internships or full-time positions in similar roles at software companies or studios, particularly those that use C++ as the primary language.”

A common way to begin a software engineering career, which is what I did, is to pursue a computer science degree and study relevant courses for the animated film industry such as computer graphics, parallel computing, and linear algebra.
Another resource is going to conferences such as Siggraph where one can attend sessions to learn more and meet people in the industry.
There are many kinds of careers possible in the animated film industry and a great resource to learn more about these careers is through Khan Academy's “Pixar in a Box.”
I am also deeply honored and thrilled that the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has selected the Taz Hair Simulation System team for a Technical Achievement Award this year.

Taz has been used on hundreds of animated characters since its creation and on nearly every Pixar film since. It has been rewarding that my technological contributions have enabled artists to make such beautiful hair in motion.

...to support the various hair styles for Brave. Taz quickly became Pixar’s de facto hair simulation system and over the past ten years, I have closely collaborated with production artists to extend the simulator to support the various artistic hairstyles of Pixar's films.

In 2010, I joined Mark Meyer, John Anderson and Andrew Witkin in their efforts to create the Taz Hair Simulation System. Our goal was to achieve the previously unachievable desired artistic look and motion of long, curly, hair for Merida, as well as...

They make me feel young again, and again, I feel very blessed.”  – Galyn Susman, Technical Director & Lighting Supervisor, Toy Story

Currently, I am a Producer, working on an unannounced feature film at Pixar. And guess what? It feels new and exciting, and my team is passionate about the project in a way that is so reminiscent of my experience on Toy Story.
So many pieces had to come together to bring me to Pixar in 1990 that I can’t help but feel very, very blessed!

I’m so thankful that I was in the right place at the right time, that I had chosen computer graphics before it was a popular thing to study, and then met the right people with the crazy ideas of making this dream a reality.

I would never have imagined at the time that we were not only making a movie, but also making history. I suppose the overriding feeling I have towards it all is a feeling of being lucky or fortunate, depending on your view of self-determination.

Now the people that we hire have no cognizance of a world where animated films weren’t predominantly made on computers. And to think that we set this entire process in motion (of course someone would have done it, but we happened to get there first) is pretty mind blowing.

A decade ago, when we hired new talent, they would often cite Toy Story as changing the way they thought about animation and animated films and would say that it set them on a career path from an early age.

“My role on the original Toy Story was as a technical director, or what we now call a ‘technical artist.’ Back then we were generalists, so I did both character and set modeling and shading and then lighting, eventually becoming a lighting supervisor along with Sharon Callahan. https://t.co/kjSD7ShPP3

I remember seeing the finished film for the first time about a month before the release, and thinking about how much the audience was going to love it.

Even though Toy Story was the first film I’ve ever worked on, there was a sense that we were working on something special. There was an energy in the air and an excitement that is still hard to describe.

I’m very proud to have been part of the original Toy Story. That sense of pride was amplified as we wrapped things up with Toy Story 4, on which I was one of the producers. I’ve been around the Toy Story characters for over half of my life, and they are like family to me.

This included getting lunches, setting up meetings, and helping out in departments like Editorial and Art. But the coolest part of my job by far was when they trained me to be one of the projectionists! I got to run film dailies for the last month or so on Toy Story.

Yes, it comes down to the people! Today, I serve as Senior VP, Talent. In this role, I oversee Pixar's department leaders and production talent, working to bring the best of our artistry to every film we make.”  – Katherine Sarafian, Production Scheduling Coordinator, Toy Story

As a crew, we had no rule books, no instruction manuals, and no idea whether our film would succeed. We made a movie we’d want to see, and poured our talents into it. I had so much fun interacting with such a stellar and interesting group of people every day.

My favorite memories working on Toy Story were those collaborative moments with really fun, interesting, and bold people, from a range of disciplines—technical, artistic, leadership—coming together to create something completely new.
I truly did not imagine Toy Story as the birth of this CG animation feature film industry, nor did I imagine I’d still be at the studio 25 years later—and still loving doing what we do!

I pitched in wherever help was needed—we had a small but mighty team, and we all did a lot!

I knew at the time that we were making something truly historic and groundbreaking, but I never dreamed back then that it would be more than a one-off.

I would update dry-erase boards with weekly quota numbers, update the production database with progress information on shots and sets/characters assets, and take photos of new hires for the ‘employee picture wall.’

“As the Production Scheduling Coordinator on Toy Story, I assisted Production Supervisor Karen Robert Jackson and the Producers with all matter of schedules, spreadsheets, quota forecasts, and production documents.

When I was little, I never thought working in animation was even a possibility. I hope that by having minorities not only on screen but also behind the scenes,

"My family has influenced my work so much. They are part of who I am. Every note I’ve given on Soul has been a direct result of thinking about my culture and how I want it portrayed on screen. It's made me want to make sure the film is authentic in every way possible. https://t.co/fUw0M0EZQD
I feel so proud and filled with joy to have the chance to be a part of something so special!” - Cheyenne Chapel, Sets Modeling and Dressing Technical Director on Soul #InsidePixar #BlackHistoryMonth

Seeing yourself represented in a film/media is such a powerful thing, it pushes people to understand one another, gives people voices that they may not think they have and give the future something dear to celebrate.
Representation matters so much and getting the chance to be a part of something that my nieces, nephews and cousins will watch and hopefully be inspired by is something I cherish.
My team valued my opinion in the film and I think it’s made my time working on Soul so fun to feel like my voice mattered.

“Being on Soul and being a black, country girl from Texas I think brings a unique perspective that many people may not have in this industry. Especially working on Soul, I had more opportunities to bring part of my culture that I am so thankful for. https://t.co/5pwkvw99Df

It means a lot to me to be a part of a project like Soul and to be able to contribute to something that helps bring more color to a world that spent the last 300 years trying to hide it.” - Christopher Carter, Animator on Soul #InsidePixar #BlackHistoryMonth
That we don't have to fit a mold or a role that is handed to us by the situation of our birth and the color of our skin.

I hope to inspire younger African Americans […] to show them that there are people that look like them being brought to the forefront of media in a positive light. To show them that the path of animation is possible for them as well.

Mama wangu, nakupenda sana! [Swahili for "My Mom, I love you very much!]” - Sean Muriithi, Animator on Soul #BlackHistoryMonth #InsidePixar

I knew early on that I did not aspire to be in the medical field because I did not possess the passion to do so like many others in my family; however, I knew I could still help the world as my Mom does through a different medium.

I know a lot of people in my community can relate when I say our parents are never too excited to hear us say, ‘I want to do arts,’ because it's always about science, business, or law. But again, the industry needs our voices and it needs us to tell our stories.

It's unfortunate to say, but there aren't a lot of African-Americans in the animation industry and I hope this film touches my community and illustrates to them that your dreams are achievable, you can make it, you just have to be willing to take those risks.

As artists, we face many challenges during the day whether they be big or small. One of those battles we face is representation. I hope when people watch SOUL, they are inspired to chase their dream regardless of what obstacles or hardships they might face.

She's a true inspiration because she is rarely faced with an issue that she cannot eradicate. I've seen her go through the toughest of battles, but she always rises to the top. I try to keep that in my mind as motivation as I'm working in this industry.

Whether I had trouble at school with a teacher, got stuck on the road with car troubles, or if I just needed someone to annoy, she was always there. She's not just a hero to me and my siblings, but to several others as well - She's a nurse and she saves lives every day.

“If I were to pick one person that inspires me the most, it would be my Mom. Since my father passed away when I was little, she's always been the champion in my eyes that comes in to save the day. https://t.co/ZqBYWJeMPF

It’s necessary for all of us to uphold the many who fought for better days, and to never lose sight that they are the expression and definition of human love & compassion.” #BlackHistoryMonth #InsidePixar
I thought I knew the meaning of Black History, but I was so wrong. Black History is necessary for all of us to know, see and learn from the many that took the high-road.

It takes real courage and love to face evil for over 400 years and walk right through it.
A few months ago, I took a trip to the National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington D.C, and I walked away with a punch to the gut.

It’s important for me to always keep in mind and heart those who’ve come before me, and the sacrifices they have made. I wouldn’t be here if it weren’t for those who believed in a brighter, better future.

MonatQue Ruffin - Animator on Soul

“Black History Month reminds me of who I am, not what I am. Black History teaches me the unwavering power of love, and the strength that comes with it.

Seeing my name on the big screen is important to me because when others see it up there, I want it to show them that what's seemingly unattainable IS possible, if you're willing to put the work in." - Frank Abney, Animator on Soul #BlackHistoryMonth #InsidePixar
Outside of Soul, my favorite experience working on a Pixar film has been growing as a filmmaker, and simply seeing my name in the credits after each film.

It pushes us to create for ourselves which I'm definitely on board for! But seeing a company such as Pixar take on a film like this, and being a part of it on multiple levels, with my voice being heard is a huge honor!

“Being a part of a film like Soul where black characters are being represented on screen means more to me than I can fully verbalize. It's not easy being in a field you love so much, and feeling like you've hardly been represented. https://t.co/cFg19RJUVC
If I could go back in time, I'd tell myself to be curious, try things, and not be afraid of failure. You learn more from failure than you do from success.” #BlackHistoryMonth #InsidePixar
Like the main character in Soul, Joe, I grew up chasing after a dream and having people around me tell me I couldn't do it and that I should pick a different career path.

Michael Yates – Story Artist on Soul

I am excited for an African American audience to see themselves represented in our film, Soul, and I hope that it motivates the next generation to create more diverse bodies of work.” #BlackHistoryMonth #InsidePixar
As a kid, I grew up loving animation and dreamed of working at Pixar. I have waited a lifetime to make this happen, so it’s a pretty big deal that I’m here now and I'm so thankful to be a part of it.

Aphton Corbin
Story Artist on Soul

“I like to think I put a piece of myself in everything that I do so of course that includes my cultural heritage as well. We draw from life, and my life takes part in the Black Experience. https://t.co/CsOwREar04

The American economy was launched with the labor of black slaves in the 17th, 18th, and 19th centuries. I believe that every month is Black History Month not just February and I am very proud of our contributions to American history.” #BlackHistoryMonth #InsidePixar

The roots of American music come out of the blues folk and gospel traditions of music that are fundamental to the African American experience. Toni Morrison's stories are American stories that feature black characters.
Fast forward to 2020 and my views have clarified. I have come to realize that African American history is actually American history.  The two cannot be separated.

In 1976, President Gerald Ford recognized Black History Month on a national level.  I remember being very excited that the federal government felt it important enough to officially recognize these achievements.

My parents were both college graduates and they taught my brother and I about many events throughout history that black people were instrumental in that did not necessarily end up in the textbooks of the time.

Robert Grahamjones - Associate Editor on Soul

“I was born in 1956 at a time when the achievements of African American people were not readily celebrated or recognized. https://t.co/JTtrnL2dZ8
That the characters they see up on the screen feel as culturally authentic as they do universal.” #BlackHistoryMonth #InsidePixar

Regardless of ethnicity, there are some themes that are universal, and I believe SOUL gets to the heart of many of those themes. That being said, I take this representation very seriously. I want to make sure this is a film my own kids and family can enjoy and be proud of.

and that having African American leads and casts weren’t such an unusual thing to see in animation. But times are changing, and I’m honored to be a part of that change. 

We relate to one another so much better when we’re given an opportunity to see the humanity in each other.

Kemp Powers
Co-director & Writer of Soul

#WorkA…

Kristina Anderson (Systems Intern)

What will you miss most about your internship?

"Definitely the people and the environment. This is the most positive and collaborative space I have been a part of and hope that I will end up here someday after I graduate!" https://t.co/zwC5fBTNzB

Sarah Radzihovsky (Research Intern) 

Where's your favorite place to hang out #InsidePixar?

"The soccer field! I've made some of my best friends at work while playing pick up every Monday and Friday. On the field, titles and roles don't matter — we're all just there to play." https://t.co/fox9zdP6Wk

Sofya Ogunseitan (Technical Director Intern - Grooming) 

What's the most valuable lesson you’ve learned in your time at Pixar?

"How to communicate with artists effectively, and take their constructive feedback when transforming 2D designs to 3D designs!" https://t.co/hGNdgE4mvz

Madeleine Fernando (PR Intern)

What's the best memory of your internship?

"Attending D23 Expo! Getting to work at the booth was an incredible experience and reminded me just how much Pixar's films have resonated with people from around the world." https://t.co/pIUrUCOuj3

Michelle Perea (Documentary Intern)

Was there a moment during your internship where you surprised yourself?

"I was nervous when tasked with creating motion graphics for Toy Story 4 bonus material, but surprised myself with my knowledge and ability to create some nice effects!" https://t.co/zawABgp9PZ

Anthony Muscarella (Technical Director Intern - Character Modeling/Rigging)

"Dream come true." https://t.co/Q05y0rU8SA
